events.name: RxJava on Android
events.description: Functional Reactive Programming will change the way you think about development. Come learn what you can do with RxJava at our next meetup.

events.name: Android Automated UI Testing
events.description: Jonathan Bejarano will be presenting on Automated UI testing for Android. We'll be meeting at the Vivint building in Lehi (Thanksgiving point).

events.name: Less sucky Activities and more testable code with Android MVP
events.description: Jeff Potter will present on some useful methods for architecting Android applications using MVP. If your are interested in writing apps that are more flexible, less buggy, and easier to test, you won't want to miss this talk.
events.how_to_find_us: Actually 3401 Ashton Blvd. exit at Thanksgiving point and head east on Clubhouse Drive. Turn north on Ashton Blvd. Take the next right into the parking lot behind Dickey's BBQ. It's the large Vivint building. Someone will be there to let you in.

events.name: SDKs, APIs, Libraries Oh my! This meetup's for everyone.
events.description:
This meetup is all about the tools we can use as developers so that we don't have to reinvent the wheel. 

Please join us for some food and drink while we discuss tools like Google Analytics, Leak Canary, Volley, and Fabric which includes Crashlytics, Digits, and more.

Existing Android Devs, please think of one library, SDK, API that you love that makes your life easier other than those mentioned above AND bring a developer friend!

Our hope with this meetup is that developers and those just starting out can collectively gather more knowledge about existing tools in the Android ecosystem that will in turn help us all develop amazing apps.

For those interested, there will also be a discussion about creating an Android Boilerplate project that existing and new developers can use to bootstrap their app development process.

As an additional bonus, I will have my new Nexus 6P in hand for you to look at and fondle should you be interested.
events.how_to_find_us: https://goo.gl/maps/DnxjXkLSzDm  The Vivint building at thanksgiving point.

events.name: CoordinatorLayout:H­ow to build advanced user interactions
events.description:
So you've got a fancy idea for your user interface but are unsure how to implement it. Come join us to add the powerful capabilities of CoordinatorLayout to your app developer tool belt.

Presenter: Jeff Hillman, professional Android developer at Chatbooks.

events.name: Kotlin: The future of Android development?

venue.name: Vivint.Solar Thankgiving Point (not the one under construction)

events.description:
The Agenda: 

Introductions, attendance, welcomes, food and drink. (15 mins)

Speed Talks. (15-25 mins.)

The speed talk topics for this meetup are about Data Binding, Broadcast Receivers, and Location Services and are presented by Bryan Bryce, Cassidy Ellis, and Jake Wilson respectively. (15-25 mins.)

Main Presentation:

Building Cleaner, Safer, Better Android Apps with the Kotlin Language presented by Jacob Moncur. 

For those who prefer a programmatic agenda:

https://gist.github.com/michaelgarnerdev/41ee994ef38c0dd1a5a3
events.how_to_find_us: Go in the building, up the elevators to the 5th floor

events.name: Dagger 2: Dependency Injection You Can Depend On
events.description:
Come learn what all the fuss is about and how to convert your application to use this powerful dependency injection tool.

This meetup is taking place 1 week later than regularly scheduled due to a scheduling conflict.

Presentation by Dustin Graham
events.how_to_find_us: Next to Dickey's BBQ and Firehouse Subs

events.name: RxJava: The Prescription Your App Needs
events.description:
Tired of callback hell? Validating forms making you rip your hair out? Come learn about why Reactive Extensions can help your app's code become easier to reason about.  

Jake Wilson has been developing for Android since 2011 at Weber State University where he graduated in computer science. He is currently working for imzy.com a startup company in downtown SLC.
events.how_to_find_us: Next to Dickey's BBQ and Firehouse Subs

events.name: AndroidN && CodeChallenge (with small prizes)
events.description:
We have a couple talks about Android N, a talk about Circular Reveal Animations, and a code challenge that includes prizes.

We also have T-shirts designed. Order one from Dustin or I. If you want to show support for the group and its costs you can chip in extra for yours, otherwise you can order the t-shirt here at cost:

https://www.customink.com/g/fuf0-00ah-jw0b

Also, if you haven't seen the survey in our slack group. We're finding out about salaries. Check out the survey here: http://goo.gl/forms/2IJeR6TlSu 

We hope to see everyone there!
events.how_to_find_us: Next to Dickey's BBQ and Firehouse Subs

events.name: DBTools for Android: Because SQLite Sucks on Its Own
events.description:
Our main topic this month is DBTools. 

DBTools for Android: Simple, fast, and powerful SQLite ORM database library for Android

There are several Android ORM database libraries available, come see how DBTools compares and what features it provides to simplify, speedup, and improve the quality of Android apps.

Presented by Jeff Campbell. Jeff Campbell has been a Java developer since 1995 and an Android developer since 2010. He has a great passion for application architecture, databases, and he is an avid open source contributor. He is currently the Android Lead for the LDS church and helps bring LDS Tools and Gospel Library to life.

In addition to an awesome presentation from Jeff, we will have several 'toolbox' talks again about various topics of Android.

Eduardo Gueiros will give the first part of a multi-part presentation on 'Async Patterns'. This will be Part I.

It is also time to say goodbye to Dustin Graham and Michael Garner. Dustin will still be working for Vivint, but he is moving to Arizona and will be telecommuting. Michael is moving to San Francisco to work on the Android Walmart app. Jake Stokes has agreed to help organize the group from now on and we are seeking at least one more organizer willing to help plan and prepare these awesome meetups. We're also looking for someone that can take on the task of documenting our meetups, gathering notes and code samples, and blogging them on the UtahAndroid.com website. Message Michael or Dustin on slack if you are interested in helping out. There is a time commitment to being an organizer. (2-4 hours a month usually for planning.) 

Also, there is only 1 more day to order your Utah Android shirt! Get it now!

https://www.customink.com/g/fuf0-00ah-jw0b

See you Thursday!
events.how_to_find_us: Next to Dickey's BBQ and Firehouse Subs

events.name: Look at that View
events.description: This coming talk will be a follow-up to the previous presentation on Custom Views and will focus on how to use the Canvas class to build custom UIs like pie-charts and graphs, along with tips for performance optimization and best practices.

events.name: Unified Architecture Patterns (MVP+) & Epoxy
events.description:
This meetup will contain 2 separate talks and Ancestry will be providing AncestryDNA kits as a door raffle so you won't want to miss out!

Talk 1 by Steve Burns:
Cross-platform Application Architecture with MVP+
In order to better design our software and share knowledge, we developed a unified architectural pattern and language around MVP

Talk 2 by Matt Bishop:
Have you ever had a RecylerView.Adapter turn into a mess of spaghetti code? Or have you ever had a project manager tell you to add section headers to your list at the last minute? Let's talk about Epoxy (https://github.com/airbnb/epoxy), a library from Airbnb to help you tame your complex adapters. We'll also talk about how this can help make clear the role of your adapters in an architecture like MVP.

NOTE: Food and drinks will be available starting at 5:30PM
events.how_to_find_us: Training Room

events.name: Reactive programming with RxJava & Auth0 (Auth Zero)
events.description:
Talk 1 by Jon Bott:
Most courses give a complex but high level overview of RxJava, without giving real-world uses, simple design patterns, or recipes to follow.

We will simplify working with RxJava and Reactive Patterns, as well as gain a simple to follow template on how best to use Reactive Programming in our UI, Network, and Data Layers.

The six things we'll cover are practical examples for:
* RxVariable: The Simplest Form
* Subjects: when to use them
* Observables: with complex tasks
* Grouping multiple complex tasks
* Observables in the UI
* Threading

Talk 2 by Michael Stringham:
Have you spent too much time and resources on authentication for your web, mobile, or native application?
Have you wondered if you "got it right" the first time? Auth0 (https://auth0.com/) is meant to alleviate these concerns with a simple and intuitive API and SDK. This platform covers authentication and identity concerns (including single sign on, social logins, multi-factor authentication, and others), which has been used to secure billions of logins every month.

NOTE: Food and drinks will be available starting at 5:30PM
events.how_to_find_us: Next to Dickey's BBQ and Firehouse Subs

events.name: Advanced Android UI Testing with Espresso
events.description:
Join us for a night of learning, networking and prizes. We'll have great presentations and at the end, a lucky attendee will got home with a Google Daydream!! Please note we're back at Vivint Smart Home for our Meetups!

We'll hear from Nora Valletta, Android Developer at Pluralsight. Here's what she'll cover:
"The Espresso framework makes it easy to interact with and perform assertions against Android views during UI tests, but did you know that Espresso also offers robust Intent validation and synchronization capabilities? Join us, and let's explore some of the lesser-known yet highly powerful tools that Espresso has to offer."

Chad Bingham will be joining us from Simple Nexus for a short toolbox talk on Koin, a dependency injection framework made specifically for Kotlin

answers.question: Please tell us a little about your experience.
What do you hope to get out of this group?
Are you willing to give presentations for meetups?

group_profile.intro: I'm passionate about apps and everything mobile. I'm the Mobile Dev Team Lead at Jive Communications developing apps on the B2B space.

answers.question: Please tell us a little about your experience.
answers.answer: I've built a few android apps as side projects. I've been doing a lot more android lately at work. Anxious to get more involved in the local android community.

answers.question: What do you hope to get out of this group?
answers.answer: Meet other android developers. Hear about what struggles they are having and what solutions they have found.

answers.question: Are you willing to give presentations for meetups?
Please tell us a little about your experience.
answers.answer:
I'm a Sr. Software Engineer that has been doing Android development since 2012, and worked on projects in web, server, desktop, ruggedized mobile (windows CE/mobile), etc. for about 9 years.

I am the creator and maintainer of two media playback libraries and miscellaneous others for Android.

answers.question: What do you hope to get out of this group?
answers.answer:
There are two main things I want to get out of this group
1. See different perspectives on topics including; architecture, libraries, IDEs, etc.
2. Introduce and help others gain a better understanding of topics I have mastery over.

answers.question: Are you willing to give presentations for meetups?

group_profile.intro: Sr. Software Engineer @ Medici Land Governance

answers.question: Please tell us a little about your experience.
answers.answer: Highly interested in mobile technology, end-to-end.
